references: Constraints and knowledge. The constraints in optimization (P) characterize the process of poisoning FRL, and their interpretations are summarized in Table 1. The constraint (2) describes how a clean agent i𝑖i initializes its policy for local training at the beginning of each round. The agent updates its model from θ(i)p−1,Lsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝1𝐿\theta_{(i)}^{p-1,L} to θ(i)p,0superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝0\theta_{(i)}^{p,0} using an update algorithm 𝒜u​p​(⋅,⋅)superscript𝒜𝑢𝑝⋅⋅\mathcal{A}^{up}(\cdot,\cdot). This update algorithm takes the agent’s current model θ(i)p−1,Lsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝1𝐿\theta_{(i)}^{p-1,L} and the global model broadcast by the server θ(0)p−1superscriptsubscript𝜃0𝑝1\theta_{(0)}^{p-1} as inputs, and outputs the agent’s new local model θ(i)p,0superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝0\theta_{(i)}^{p,0}. Constraint (3) describes the local update of each clean agent at local step q𝑞q in round p𝑝p. The agent uses its current policy, represented by θ(i)p,q−1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝𝑞1\theta_{(i)}^{p,q-1}, to roll out an observation sequence O(i)p,q−1superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑖𝑝𝑞1O_{(i)}^{p,q-1}. Then, based on this observation, the agent updates its policy from θ(i)p,q−1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝𝑞1\theta_{(i)}^{p,q-1} to θ(i)p,qsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝𝑞\theta_{(i)}^{p,q} by maximizing an objective function J​(⋅)𝐽⋅J(\cdot), defined by the agent’s specific RL algorithm. Moreover, constraints (5) and (6) characterize the malicious agent’s local initialization and update, respectively. Their interpretation is similar to the constraints (2) and (3), except that the local update of a malicious agent is based on the manipulated observation O^^𝑂\widehat{O}. Constraint (7) captures the budget constraint for the attacker, where D​(⋅,⋅)𝐷⋅⋅D(\cdot,\cdot) represents the distance between the perturbed (poisoned) observations and the clean observations, which is restricted by a cost budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. The attack power ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon represents the degree of poisoning that is allowed, and it is used to define the limit of the change that can be made to the clean data. Finally, the constraint (8) models the aggregation step of the central server by an aggregation algorithm 𝒜a​g​gsuperscript𝒜𝑎𝑔𝑔\mathcal{A}^{agg}. The inputs of 𝒜a​g​gsuperscript𝒜𝑎𝑔𝑔\mathcal{A}^{agg} are the server’s current model θ(0)p−1superscriptsubscript𝜃0𝑝1\theta_{(0)}^{p-1} and the models sent from agents {θ(i)p−1,L}superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝1𝐿\{\theta_{(i)}^{p-1,L}\}. The output of 𝒜a​g​gsuperscript𝒜𝑎𝑔𝑔\mathcal{A}^{agg} is the server’s new global model θ(0)psuperscriptsubscript𝜃0𝑝\theta_{(0)}^{p}.

references: Table 2 shows the knowledge of the three parties involved in FL, namely, the coordinator, the attacker, and the agents. The table clarifies the knowledge of each party to guarantee the data privacy expected from FL. The coordinator only has knowledge of the submitted models and the global policy, while the agents only have knowledge of their local data, policy, and the broadcast global model. The attacker only has knowledge of its own observations, manipulations, model, and the broadcast global policy. This ensures that the agents’ private data is kept confidential.
